abstract: pmc BMC Womens Health BMC Womens Health 68 bmcwh BMC Women's Health 1472-6874 BMC PMC12487473 PMC12487473.1 12487473 12487473 41034810 10.1186/s12905-025-03971-1 3971 1 Case Report Recurrent Granulomatous Mastitis in the Contralateral Breast Following Radical Mastectomy for Breast Cancer: A Case Report and Literature Review Chen Jie Zhang Bo zora19702006@163.com Zhou Tongtong https://ror.org/037cjxp13 grid.415954.8 0000 0004 1771 3349 Department of Ultrasound, China–Japan Friendship Hospital, 1 10 2025 2025 25 478356 464 20 9 2024 11 8 2025 01 10 2025 02 10 2025 03 10 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Granulomatous mastitis (GM) is a rare, chronic, benign inflammatory breast disease with an unknown etiology, primarily affecting young women. It is often characterized by the presence of a painful mass, skin changes, and persistent inflammation, which can clinically resemble breast cancer. Due to the absence of specific imaging signatures and a poorly understood pathogenic mechanism, diagnosis is primarily achieved through exclusion. We present the case of a 31-year-old woman who, three years after undergoing a radical mastectomy for triple-negative breast cancer in her right breast, was diagnosed with GM in her left breast. The diagnosis was based on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), conventional and contrast-enhanced ultrasound, and confirmed through histological analysis. The patient has experienced recurrent episodes of GM over the past three years. Notably, this case represents the first reported instance of granulomatous mastitis occurring in the contralateral breast following a radical mastectomy for breast cancer. Diagnostic imaging and biopsy confirmed a diagnosis of invasive breast cancer. The patient subsequently underwent a right mastectomy and right axillary lymph node dissection. A B C Discussion Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), characterized by the lack of expression of ER, PR, HER2, represents the most aggressive and lethal subtype of breast cancer [ 4 5 6 7 8 9 We report a case of breast cancer treated with regular chemotherapy following radical mastectomy, in which refractory GM developed in the contralateral breast. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first documented case of GM occurring in the opposite breast after radical mastectomy.
